title: 2CECEBBF-24D4-429F-B4AA-37C6E14DF68E
important_topics: Tactics scammers use to manipulate victims
The role of banks and credit unions in preventing scams
The importance of staying connected with loved ones
The impact of fraud on future relationships
Lack of resources for law enforcement to handle fraud cases
Need for improved customer service for fraud victims
Financial institutions responsibility to protect customers
fraud_tips: Beware of individuals with a backstory involving trustworthy professions like military, pilot, or doctor, especially if they are abroad and cannot meet in person.
Be wary of sob stories where the scammer suddenly needs money for their children, animals, or elderly parents.
Be careful of individuals who always use two first names and are overly caring and attentive.

Oil rig workers are typically on an oil rig for 14 or 21 days, depending on how physically intensive their work is. No one is on a rig for three months or longer without a break. Oil rig workers don't pay for transport to or from the rig.
Beware of being isolated from your friends and family.
Be cautious of gaslighting, where scammers will confuse and deny events to make you second-guess yourself.
Be aware of the use of silence, where scammers will disappear online for days or weeks if you don't send them money.
Scammers often pick up on keywords but skip over other words, so if you see that happen, be aware.
Reject the belief that it's the victim's fault for 'falling' for a scam.
tactics: Creating a backstory with a trustworthy profession (military, pilot, doctor)
Isolating victims from friends and family
Using silence as a form of manipulation
